summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the proposed protective order in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The government opposes two specific modifications requested by the defense: (1) allowing the defense to publicly name victims who have spoken publicly about Epstein or Maxwell, and (2) imposing restrictions on the government's use of its own investigative materials. The government argues these requests lack legal basis and would harm victim privacy.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) who is seeking modifications to the protective order. The government is opposing her requests.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and alleged co-conspirator; the criminal conduct involves victims of both Epstein and Maxwell.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter is addressed to her.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The government attorney who signed and submitted this letter to the court.

connections.description: The document repeatedly references victims of both Epstein and Maxwell, and the defense seeks to name individuals who have spoken publicly about either of them, indicating their alleged joint criminal activity.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case. This letter is a formal legal submission from the government to the judge regarding case procedures.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is representing the government prosecuting Maxwell and is formally opposing the defense's motions in this letter.

events.title: Defense Submits Letter on Protective Order
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel submitted a letter and proposed protective order to the court, which this government letter is responding to.

events.title: Protective Order Negotiations
events.description: The government and defense counsel conferred several times via telephone and email between July 9 and July 28, 2020, regarding the terms of a protective order.

events.title: Epstein Prosecution and Suicide
events.description: Referenced is the prior criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein (19 Cr. 490) and his subsequent suicide, which led to the dismissal of that indictment.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government strongly opposes the defense's request to publicly name victims who have ever spoken about Epstein or Maxwell in any public forum, calling it 'extraordinarily broad, unnecessary, and inappropriate.'
The government argues victim privacy is protected by the Crime Victims' Rights Act and that public identification could deter other victims from reporting crimes.

The government's proposed order would allow the defense to name only victims who affirmatively identify themselves on the record in *this* specific criminal case, not those who spoke publicly in the past.
The government also opposes the defense's unprecedented request to restrict how the government uses its own investigative documents with witnesses, stating such restrictions lack legal basis.
The document reveals an ongoing, contentious pretrial dispute over the scope of victim anonymity and the handling of discovery materials.
